zh-TW.content: 哈囉，歡迎來到Kono Summit，這裡是知識和學習自然發生的地方。
您正在聽布魯斯・D・培理與歐普拉・溫芙蕾的《你經歷了什麼？談創傷、韌性與治癒》，第一部分。
本書透過一系列兩位作者間的深度談話來呈現。
歐普拉・溫芙蕾為聞名全球的談話節目主持人，她的創傷經驗來自命途多舛的成長經歷。
童年時期，她經常被毆打，傷勢曾嚴重到她幾乎無法站立。
她說明這些經驗是如何影響她的行為和個性，再進而影響到她成年後的生活。
即使如此，歐普拉仍有辦法治癒她的創傷，並透過訪談數千位在生命中遭受創傷折磨的人們來進一步讓大眾意識到這個議題。
她也利用自身的豐厚財力來資助受創傷影響的孩童們。
布魯斯・D・培理醫生是一名兒童心理學家，他一生致力研究大腦以及創傷能如何對這個器官的重要區域造成實際的生理影響。
他專精研究創傷對於發展中大腦的衝擊。
對他而言，過去能左右現在，同時也是治癒受創傷之人的一個關鍵。
他表示，最根本的問句不是「你有什麼問題？」，而是「你經歷了什麼？」。
詢問後面的第二個問題「能幫助我們每個人稍微多了解經歷——不論其是好是壞——如何形塑我們」。
兩位作者透過敘述真實故事，讓我們能進入受創傷之人的生活中深刻體會。
作者帶領我們了解行為中反映的心理作用以及大腦聯動的生理影響。
也詳細解釋了腦部中針對健康與不健康的壓力設定。
本書建構了一個全景，描繪出每個人是如何依據對他們身上「已發生的事」的理解來回應生命中的事件。
這個主題事關我們全部的人。
歐普拉和培理醫生自個體經驗進展到整個群體和文化的創傷經驗，最終擴展討論到在缺乏關係的現代世界裡，人們所體驗到的創傷分析。
這本書能夠改變我們看待自身、他人和世界的方式。
過去也許為當前的生活帶來創傷和負面的影響，但仍有希望。
詢問「經歷了什麼？」就是理解的第一步，而在理解之後，便能帶來知識和治癒機會。

en-US.content: Hello and welcome to Kono Summit, where knowledge and learning happen naturally.
You’re listening to What Happened to You? Conversations on Trauma, Resilience, and Healing by Bruce D. Perry and Oprah Winfrey – Part 1.
The book is presented as a series of in-depth conversations between the two authors.
Oprah Winfrey is a world-famous talk show host who had experienced trauma in a troubled upbringing.
As a child, she was regularly beaten so badly that she could barely stand.
She explains how these experiences affected her behavior and personality into her adult life.
However, Oprah was able to heal her trauma and went on to bring public awareness to the issue by interviewing thousands of people who suffered trauma in their lives.
She has also used her wealth to help children affected by trauma.
Dr. Bruce D. Perry, a child psychologist, has spent his life studying the brain and how trauma can actually biologically affect important areas of this organ.
He specializes in the impact of trauma on the developing brain.
For him, the past determines the present and is also the key to healing traumatized people.
He states that the fundamental question should not be “What’s wrong with you?” but “What happened to you?”
Asking the second question “can help each of us know a little more about how experiences–both good and bad–shape us.”
The authors describe real-life stories, making us vividly enter the lives of people who have suffered trauma.
They take us through the psychological effects in behavior and also the connected biological effects in the brain.
The brain’s healthy and unhealthy stress settings are explained in detail.
The book builds up a comprehensive picture of how everyone responds to events in their lives according to “what happened” to them.
The topic involves all of us.

Oprah and Dr. Perry move on from individuals to convey the traumatic experiences of whole communities and cultures, eventually widening the discussion to analyze the traumas experienced by everyone in the relationship-starved modern world.
This book can change the way we see ourselves, other people, and the world.
The past may be traumatic and negatively affect the present, but there is hope.
Asking “What happened?” is the first step to understanding, and after understanding may come knowledge and healing.

name.zh-TW: When the Past Haunts the Present

description.zh-TW: When the Past Haunts the Present

zh-TW.content: 第二部分，當過往經歷纏繞著今日
作者們提供一個相對單純且好理解的例子，讓我們認識創傷經驗和它在整個個人生涯中會造成的影響。
他們針對一個退役後患有創傷後壓力症候群的軍人個案進行討論。
在退役多年後，此名男子聽到突發的巨響，像是摩托車引擎的逆火聲，就會感到恐慌。
這種「刺激觸發物」會讓他想起過去戰爭的記憶。
問題就在於，在這些被觸發的時刻，這名退役軍人會相信他真的身處戰爭中。
雖然如此，他只是遭受長期的創傷影響折磨，並不是發瘋。
培理醫生解釋道，當我們了解某人經歷了什麼，我們就可以理解他們的行為。
他說：「一旦你看到了看似無意識行為背後的東西，一切就都合理了。」
培理醫生描述壓力對於大腦的影響，以及它如何導致較原始的大腦下部去影響、甚至抵銷掉較理性的大腦上部運作。
他用圖表解釋大腦是以對漸增複雜度的反應而被分為四層。
像這名軍人的案例中，他的創傷對最下部、最原始的腦部造成了影響，這區塊的腦部對實際環境中的訊號做出未經思考的反射反應。
而在戰爭中，這種立即反應能幫助軍人活下去。
如果是由大腦最上部做反應，理性思考的腦皮層需要花時間去處理每個危險事件，這樣會讓軍人很快就被殺死。
這名軍人需要他大腦的原始反應部分來指揮控制。
培理醫生將這個大腦部分稱之為「爬蟲腦」，像是蜥蜴等動物會運用其對周遭的改變做出迅雷不及掩耳的反應。
很不幸地，這名軍人一再重複的戰鬥經驗已對他大腦的生物結構造成實際改變。
大腦下部仍會對會觸發過去創傷性經驗的訊號做出反應。
而當戰爭經驗已過去多年，這名退役軍人當前的恐慌情況會讓腦皮層這個大腦最上部區域的機能被覆蓋。
他的「爬蟲腦」區域告訴他過往經歷仍在持續進行中，因此讓他無法分辨過去與現在。
在許多案例中，要發現特定的創傷事件和它們與負面行為模式的聯結並不總是這麼容易。
由於兒童的大腦還在發展中，因此他們的情況更經常是這樣。
作者們藉由提供真實生活中的案例，進一步討論兒童成長過程中，創傷對於他們大腦造成的影響。
舉例而言，一個受創傷的孩子可能會將某個特定氣味與不好的經驗聯結在一起，並且在散發該氣味的環境中做出讓大人不解的行為。
這個孩童可能會變得孤僻或暴力，取決於他或她過去如何反應。
同樣地，男性教師對著一名學童大吼的行為可能會觸發孩童面對家暴父親的記憶並引起其過度反應，因為這會讓學童回想起過往——或實際上仍正經歷——的創傷事件。
對於童年創傷的特定壓力反應可能會導致不穩定且「失調」，所以這些兒童長大後會用偏差的「編碼簿」來看待並體驗這個世界，其讓腦部本能區域過度活化，阻止面對社會互動的穩定反應和造成無法處理每日生活壓力。
作者們表示：「『你經歷了什麼？』對於理解你現在的境遇是很重要的。」

en-US.content: Part 2  When the Past Haunts the Present
The authors give us a relatively simple and comprehensible example of a traumatic experience and its effect throughout an individual’s life.
They discuss the case of a soldier with PTSD (post-traumatic stress disorder) after his service.
Years later, the man would panic if he heard sudden loud noises such as the sound of a motorcycle engine backfiring.
These “triggers” brought back memories of battle.
The problem was that in these moments, the ex-soldier actually believed he was in battle.
Nevertheless, he was not crazy but just suffering the long-term effects of trauma.
When we know what happened to someone, Dr. Perry explains, we can understand their behavior.
He says that “seemingly senseless behavior makes sense once you look at what is behind it.”
Dr. Perry describes the effects of stress on the brain, and how it causes the lower, more primitive areas to influence and even cancel out the functioning of the higher, more rational areas.
He explains how the brain can be divided into four layers of response of increasing complexity via a diagram.
In the case of the soldier, his trauma affected the lowest, most primitive part, which responds without thinking to signals from the physical environment.
In battle, this immediate response helps soldiers stay alive.
If the highest part of the brain, the rational thinking cortex had to take time to process every dangerous event, the soldier would soon have been killed.
The soldier needed the primitive reactive part of his brain to be in control.
Dr. Perry calls it the “reptilian brain” which animals such as lizards use to respond at lightning speed to changes around them.
Unfortunately, the soldier’s repeated combat experiences actually changed the biology of his brain.
The lower area remained responsive to signals that could trigger past traumatic experiences.
The highest part of the brain, the cortex, would then be overridden as the ex-soldier panicked many years after his war experiences.
He could not distinguish between past and present because his “reptilian brain” area was signaling that the past was still present.
In many cases, it is not always so easy to discover specific traumatic events and their link to negative behavior patterns.
This is often true with children, whose brains are still developing.
Giving real-life examples, the authors move on to discuss the effects of trauma on children’s brains as they grow up.
For example, a traumatized child may associate a certain smell with a bad experience and behave in a way by which adults are puzzled when exposed to the smell.
The child might become withdrawn or violent, depending on how he or she reacted before.

Similarly, a male teacher who shouts at a student may trigger memories of an abusive father and cause an overreaction because the student is recalling–or, in fact, now living within–a past traumatic event.

Certain stress responses to childhood traumas may lead to imbalance and being “dysregulated,” so these children grow up to see and experience the world with a warped “codebook” in which the over-activation of the instinctive areas of the brain prevents a balanced response to social interactions and an inability to cope with the stresses of everyday existence.
The authors demonstrate that “‘What happened to you?’ is so important in understanding what’s going on with you now.”

zh-TW.content: 第三部分，回到最初的起點
作者們探討人類經驗的根本結構。
討論到針對嬰兒的研究揭示了人類生命富有規律的自然本質。
培理醫生表示：「所有生命都是有規律的。」
在嬰兒時期，存在一種感受自然壓力的模式。
舉例來說，嬰兒餓了想吃東西時就會哭。
而這個壓力會根據照顧者對於他們需求的關注程度來調節。
若嬰兒經常受到關注，他們會發展出較強的壓力反應能力來應付未來生活狀況。
他們的大腦會發展來處理成年生活的複雜情況。
而因早年擁有令人滿意的關係，他們便能從之後的人際關係中獲得滿足。
作者們更深入且詳細地討論平衡與調節的概念，揭示心理作用與生物機制在大腦中的聯結。
他們描述了核心調節網絡這個人類腦中的壓力反應系統。
嬰兒若是反覆受到擾亂或忽視，就無法體驗到健全的規律，而且他們的核心調節網絡可能會發展出「敏化作用」，意味著他們在成長過程面臨到人生中難解的挑戰時，會傾向做出異常的行為反應。
被忽視的嬰兒則可能會面臨自我價值喪失以及對他人缺乏信任感。
作者們討論到一些學童的案例，這些學童因為覺得自己不重要而拒絕參與學校事務，認為為什麼需要嘗試呢？
這些孩童因為他們過去的創傷而做出解離行為，並退縮封閉自己。
這即是原始本能裡的「逃離」反應，在這些孩童的嬰兒時期就建立在他們的核心調節網絡中。
另外有些孩童可能會拒絕配合並在教室到處搗亂。
他們的反應是對外的，為嬰兒時期就建立在他們核心調節網絡中的「戰鬥」反應。
培理醫生強調，不同的異常行為需要先用「經歷了什麼？」去理解，而後才能開啟有意義的療程和治癒行為。
培理醫生將嬰兒對日常需求的滿足與獎勵的概念做聯結。
他說道：每個人都需要感覺到每天固定收到獎勵，因為這種「從痛苦中解脫的愉悅會成為一種效力強大的獎勵。」
壓力雖是生活的一部分，但我們大腦中神經網絡對壓力的反應以及克服一個挑戰所產生的滿足感，也都是生活在運轉的一部分。
他表示，我們都有著所謂的「獎勵桶」需要被裝填。
在嬰兒時期就建立健康的壓力反應系統（核心調節網絡）的人們，傾向用所獲得的正向關係來裝填他們的獎勵桶，這些正向關係可能來自工作、學校、朋友或家人關係中，或發生在像嗜好或運動愛好這種有規律性、重複性的活動中。
但是，建立健康的關係對嬰兒時期壓力反應系統就失衡的人們而言可能很困難。
他們更有可能用酒精、毒品及吃不健康食物的「安慰性進食」來滿足心理上的需求或逃避壓力，填滿他們的獎勵桶。
培理醫生主張，嬰兒時期的體驗和大腦對其做出的反應能夠生成一種對世界的歸屬感，而這種「關係健康」是人們福祉必不可缺的要素。
就如同培理醫生所說：「人際關係是裝填我們獎勵桶的最健康的方式。與他人的聯結能夠調節我們，並給予正向回饋。」

en-US.content: Part 3  Back to the Beginning
The authors explore the fundamental structure of human experience.
They discuss how studies of infants reveal the rhythmic nature of human life.
Dr. Perry states that “All life is rhythmic.”
In infancy, there is a pattern of feeling natural stress.
For example, babies cry when wanting food.
This stress is regulated by the caregivers’ attention to their needs.
Regularly attended to, infants develop stronger stress response capabilities for future life situations.
Their brain develops to deal with the complexities of adult life.
They obtain satisfaction through relationships, having had satisfactory early ones.
The authors discuss the idea of balance and regulation in more depth and detail, revealing the connection of the psychological effects and biological mechanisms in the brain.
They describe the core regulatory networks (CRNs) that are the human stress response systems in the brain.

If there is repeated disruption or neglect, then the infants will not experience the healthy rhythm and may develop a “sensitization” of their CRNs, meaning they will tend to act in dysfunctional ways to challenging life events as they grow up.
Infants who are neglected may experience a loss of self-worth and lack of trust in others.
The authors discuss cases of schoolchildren who refuse to participate in school because they feel they don’t matter, so what’s the point of trying?
These children experience dissociation as a result of their past trauma and retreat into themselves.
This is a primitive “flight” response established in their CRNs in infancy.
Other children may refuse to cooperate and cause disruption in the classroom.
Their response is external, a “fight” response that became set in their CRNs as infants.
Dr. Perry emphasizes that different dysfunctional behaviors need to be understood by asking the question “What happened?” before any meaningful treatment or healing can begin.
Dr. Perry links the infant’s need for satisfaction of their daily needs to the idea of reward.
Everyone, he says, needs to feel rewarded on a daily basis because “the pleasure that comes from the relief of distress becomes a powerful reward.”
Stress is a part of life, but so is our response to it in the neural networks in our brains, and the satisfying feeling a challenge has been overcome.
He states that we all have “reward buckets” that need to be filled.

People who have developed healthy stress response systems (CRNs) during infancy will tend to fill their reward buckets through the positive relationships they may have at work, school, with friends or family, or with rhythmic, repeated activities such as hobbies or sports.
However, people with dysregulated stress response systems from infancy may find it difficult to form healthy relationships.
They are much more likely to fill their reward buckets by using alcohol or drugs and by “comfort eating”—eating unhealthy foods to satisfy psychological needs or escape stress.

Dr. Perry claims that the experiences and the resulting responses of the brain during infancy can create a feeling of belonging in the world and that “relational health” is essential for human well-being.
As Dr. Perry says, “The healthiest way to refill our reward bucket is through relationships. Connectedness regulates and rewards us.”

zh-TW.content: 第四部分，共同創傷經驗
培理醫生的研究顯示：「你與家庭、社群和文化之間的聯結關係比你面對逆境的奮鬥史還更能預知你的心理健康。」
在嬰兒到兒童時期就會建立起這種聯結關係。
作者們討論到童年創傷對往後人生有多麼長遠廣泛的影響，而他們描述了可能會對個人有深遠負面影響的經驗。
超過50%的人都經歷過童年創傷。
在一些案例，社群或種族族群中的所有成員都有過創傷經驗。
承繼這項研究，作者們接著帶入創傷和壓力對世代之間的影響這個想法。
歐普拉說道：「好幾百萬的成年人帶著傷痛過了一輩子，還傳承給他們的孩子。」
培理醫生為此舉了一個容易理解的例子。
一位受過創傷的母親可能會因為她藉濫用毒品來填滿自己的獎勵桶而疏於關注她的女兒， 更因此無法給予她的孩子自嬰兒時就需要的照顧。
這名嬰兒將會發展出不健全的行為，而這些行為可能又會在輪到她為人母親時繼續傳給自己的孩子。
這個現象可能會以群體共有的層級發生。
作者們講述黑人奴隸對狗有共同恐懼，因為狗作為他們的白人主人控制他們的工具。
這種恐懼便在他們歷史悠遠的社群中，經由照顧者傳給嬰兒。
作者們由此帶入整個文化層級的情緒傳染觀念，以及其如何影響大腦，並可能導致群體中多個個體的核心調節網絡敏感化。
社會性的情緒傳染也可能到達刻板印象的層級，且引發針對不同群體或不同政治觀點的種族歧視和無法容忍。
研究顯示，白人警察更容易懷疑黑人，因為他們成長過程中接受到的訊息讓他們相信黑人較有可能為罪犯。
這些警察可能不是有意識的種族歧視者，但在遇到黑人時，他們的壓力反應系統和核心調節網絡就會被觸發。
整個社群不僅可能會被像是毒品濫用和失敗的家庭關係這類行為問題所界定，健康問題也可能是其因。
舉例來說，糖尿病更常發生在邊緣社群裡，這群人遭受到更多的童年創傷且在社會中感覺受到威脅。
身體在壓力之下會釋放出更多胰島素，進而使得血糖升高，而這正是引發糖尿病的主要因素。
培理醫生表示：「創傷能滲透到生活的各方各面：世世代代之間皆有它的蹤跡，它的身影遍及各個家庭、社群、體制、文化和社會。」

en-US.content: Part 4  Communal Trauma
Dr. Perry’s research has shown that “your connectedness to family, community, and culture is more predictive of your mental health than your history of adversity.”
This connectedness is established from infancy into childhood.
The authors discuss how widespread the effects of childhood trauma are, which they describe as experiences that can have significant negative impacts on an individual.
Over 50% of people have had traumatic childhood experiences.
In some cases, all members of a community or ethnic group may experience trauma.
Following on from this research, the authors introduce the idea of the effects of trauma and stress between generations.
Oprah says that “there are countless millions of adults carrying that hurt through their lives, passing it on to their children.”
Dr. Perry gives an easily understandable example.
A traumatized mother may neglect her daughter because she fills her own reward bucket by abusing drugs and thus has been unable to give the child the care she has needed since infancy.
The baby will develop dysfunctional behavior which she may in turn pass on to her own children.
This phenomenon can occur at a communal level.
The authors describe black slaves’ communal fear of dogs, which their white masters used to control them.
This fear was passed on from carers to infants in their historical communities.
Thus, they introduce the idea of emotional contagion at a cultural level and how this affects the brain and may sensitize the core regulatory networks in multiple individuals in a community.
Social emotional contagion can also be at the level of stereotyping and lead to racism and intolerance of different groups or different political opinions.
Studies have shown that white police officers are more likely to suspect black people because they have been brought up to believe that blacks are more likely to be criminals.
The police officers may not be consciously racist, but their stress response systems and CRNs are triggered when encountering black people.
Whole communities may be characterized not only by behavior problems, such as drug abuse and failed family relationships, but also by health problems.
For example, diabetes is more common in marginalized communities, who have more childhood trauma and feel threatened socially.
Bodies release more insulin under stress, raising blood sugar levels, a major contributor to diabetes.
Dr. Perry states that “trauma permeates all aspects of life: it echoes through the generations, across families, communities, institutions, cultures, and societies.”

zh-TW.content: 第五部分，治癒個人
作者們討論到，要治癒創傷個體並建立他們的韌性是有可能的。
沒有人生來就具備韌性，韌性是要透過早年與照顧者之間健全且規律有序的互動來達成。
藉由反覆自然發生的壓力事件以及其有節奏且重複的規律，帶領我們發展韌性，並用上大腦的全部區域以平衡的眼界看待這個世界。
治療創傷時，我們應該要認知到受創傷影響的人們腦中有「已致敏化」且功能失調的神經網絡在運作，而這些是不能單靠心理治療或富有同情的照護與關心就能擺脫的。
話雖如此，若人們能運用位於腦皮層中大腦較上部的意識處理區域去理解自身發生的事，他們就能有意識地去改變。
腦皮層的思考區域可以改變我們的態度與看待世界的方式。
因此，藉著和他人的正向互動與引導，人們就能生成新的神經網絡，用其全新的一套聯結進行健全且有規律調節的運作。
舊有的網絡仍然存在，但它們已不再被使用。
這需要溯及一個人的過往，然後從那裡著手改造。
培理醫生說：「心理治療就像是開上你那佈滿塵土、只有兩條車道的小破路，沿著它開並在旁鋪上一條四個車道寬的高速公路。舊路依舊，但你已不再常常行駛在其顛簸之上了。」
舉例來說，學校中作亂的青少年不應該被用其躁進侵犯的行為來評斷，因為該行為只是一種症狀。
它是當下正在發生的事，而非「已發生的事」。
這個行為可能會是一個年紀較小的孩子所做，因為那就是他或她的反應方式。
這名青少年需要的是引導，讓他或她透過配對過往創傷事件去了解其反應背後的原因，而不是只告訴他們「如何舉止得宜」。
事實上，很多問題孩童可能一開始會拒絕老師或是寄養父母的關照。
培理醫生說：經常有寄養父母跟他說「他的所作所為幾乎像是故意要讓他被懲罰一樣。」這樣的話。
原因來自於這名青少年已習慣了混亂的情況。
他的大腦神經網絡已套用了接收混亂輸入的程式。
相較於面對改變自身行為的挑戰，處於混亂之中對他來說更自在，因為混亂是他對世界的預設看法。
照顧者需要審視每個人的過往歷史，並漸進地鼓勵個人去反思，然後讓他或她開始去改變其對環境的反應，從異常失調轉變為規律調節。
否則，便會像歐普拉所說：「我們只是在追著症狀跑，沒有在治癒人們。」
培理醫生詳盡地描述教育神經序列模式，其用來激勵受過創傷的兒童進行「調節、聯結和推理」，而這個過程是用有規律的健全經驗、正向互動以及自我省思來重新建構問題兒童。
所需要的是與社會所有區域中受創傷的個體進行更多聯繫往來，並在「精神支持人際網」的關係範疇內提供每個人一條「神經序列」治療之路。

en-US.content: Part 5  Healing Individuals
The authors discuss how it is possible to heal traumatized individuals and build their resilience.
None of us are born with resilience but attain it through healthy regulated early interactions with carers.
Repetition of natural stress events and their rhythmic, repeated regulation leads to resilience and a balanced view of the world using all the areas of the brain.

In treating trauma, we should recognize that “sensitized” and dysfunctional neural networks operate in the brains of those affected. These cannot be got rid of just by therapy or sympathetic care and attention.
However, people can intentionally change if they can understand what happened to them by using the higher conscious processing areas in the brain located in the cortex.
The thinking area of the cortex can change our attitudes and views of the world.
Consequently, with positive interactions with others and guidance, people can create new neural networks with a new set of associations to function healthily and in a regulated way.
The old networks are still there, but they are no longer used.
This involves looking at a person’s history and working from there.
Dr. Perry says that “therapy is taking your two-lane dirt road and building a four-lane freeway alongside it. The old road stays, but you don’t use it much anymore.”
For example, a disruptive teenager in school should not be judged by the aggressive behavior because this is just a symptom.
It’s what’s happening, not “what happened.”
The behavior may be of a much younger child because that is how he or she responds.
The teenager needs to be guided to understand why he or she reacts this way by matching traumatic events in his or her past, instead of simply telling them “how to behave well.”
In fact, many troubled children may at first reject care from teachers or foster parents.
Dr. Perry says that foster parents often tell him things like, “He almost acts like he wants to get punished.”
This is because the teenager has been used to chaos.
His brain’s neural networks are programmed to receive chaotic input.
He feels more comfortable with chaos than with the challenge of changing his behavior because chaos is his default view of the world.
Carers need to look at each person’s history and gradually encourage the individual to reflect and begin to change from dysregulated to regulated responses to his or her environment.
Otherwise, as Oprah says, “We are chasing symptoms, not healing people.”

Dr. Perry describes in detail the Neurosequential Model in Education that is being used to encourage traumatized children to “regulate, relate, and reason,” a process of rebuilding troubled children by healthy rhythmic experiences, positive interactions, and self-reflection.
What is needed is more engagement with traumatized individuals in all areas of society and providing everyone with a “neurosequential” road to healing within a “therapeutic web” of relationships.

zh-TW.content: 第六部分，我們能治癒世界嗎？
歐普拉加深「精神支持人脈網」這個概念的討論深度，她提及現代化前的傳統文化結構，並比較其生活方式以及現代世界的社會和文化環境。
她講述與來自原住民文化長者們認識的經驗。
他們的社群雖較小卻融合，能夠養育出安定平衡且有規律調節的社群成員。
諷刺的是，承受過現代國家殖民、帶來創傷與破壞的文化可提供許多方式解決現代人的問題。
他們的文化和實踐也能更有效地治癒遭受創傷的個體，藉由強調與重建正向的共有經驗。
相較於許多現代社會，傳統大家庭和關係緊密的社群也就代表著情緒支持人際網中幾乎都存在富同情心之人供人們傾訴。
如歐普拉所說：「許多治癒的實踐方法和儀式都與重新產生聯結有關——即是直率清楚地表達聯結的源頭。」
舞蹈與歌唱儀式提供了參與規律性活動的機會和歸屬感，而不致成癮的天然藥草和藥物被用來讓困頓不安的個體平靜下來。
對培理醫生而言，這些實踐做法即代表重新建構大腦的核心調節網絡：這些儀式和社交實踐提供規律來重設大腦本身並治癒它。
歐普拉和培理醫生接續討論現代社會人們越來越少產生聯結的狀態。
創傷現在占人類生活情形中很大的一部分。
人際關係的缺乏是個普遍廣泛的情況。
舉例說明，單親母親被期望要為她們的孩子提供家庭和社群所有功能。
但這是不可能的任務。
這些孩童可能會在整個社區都是核心調節網絡敏感（功能失調）的人群中長大，然後他們會再將創傷和調節異常傳給自己的孩子。
讓情況更糟的是，這個問題正在影響著現今世界的每個人。
根據培理醫生的說法：「人類大腦不是為現代世界所設計。」
它適合歐普拉所述的較小社群內的共有生活。
但是，隨著科技發展，人們在他們的電子裝置上花費愈來愈多的時間，而在每日彼此間的往來關係中花費的時間卻少之又少。
父母若因手機或電腦而分心，很顯然就不會全心關注孩子。
這會造成兒童神經網絡功能失調，並導致不健康的規律和獎勵模式。
現代小孩在成長的過程中，容易缺乏壓力因應能力，也不易產生對他人的情感。
兒童和青少年花費大量的時間在網路上。
但網路上的關係和互動缺少緊密社交關係擁有的深度，而這種深度正是健全的心理發展所需。
研究顯示，現在的大學生與二十年前相比，少了30%的同理能力。
而持續成長的都市環境正打造一個數百萬陌生人都是離群孤立個體的世界。
孤立離群、孤獨寂寞和憂鬱感受是現代生活中常見的情況，然而在傳統文化中，人們往往會有大約六十到一百人的「精神支持人際網」作為根基。
這個變化的結果就產生一種影響整個人種的的集體傷痛和創傷。

en-US.content: Part 6  Can We Heal the World?

Oprah deepens the discussion of the “therapeutic web” concept by referring to the structure of traditional and pre-modern cultures and comparing their way of life to the social and cultural environment of the modern world.
She describes her experiences of meeting elders from aboriginal cultures.
Their smaller integrated communities were able to nurture balanced and regulated community members.
Ironically, the cultures colonized, traumatized and destroyed by modern nations can provide many of the solutions to modern people’s problems.
Their cultures and practices could also more effectively heal traumatized individuals by emphasizing and reestablishing positive shared experiences.
Compared to many modern societies, traditional extended families and close communities also meant there was almost always someone sympathetic present in the therapeutic web to talk to.
As Oprah says, “Many of the healing practices and rituals involve reconnection—explicit articulation of the origins of connection.”
Dancing and song rituals provided rhythmic activities and a sense of belonging, and non-addictive natural herbs and medicines were used to calm troubled individuals.
For Dr. Perry, these practices would mean the rebuilding of the brain’s core regulatory networks: the rituals and social practices provide the rhythms that can reset and heal the brain itself.
Oprah and Dr. Perry go on to discuss the state of modern societies in which people are becoming less connected.
Trauma is now a large part of the human condition.
There is a widespread poverty of relationships.
For example, single mothers are expected to provide all the functions of a family and community for their children.
This is an impossible task.
Children may grow up in whole communities composed of people with sensitized (dysfunctional) CRNs, and they will pass the trauma and dysregulation to their own children.
To make matters worse, the problem is affecting everyone nowadays.
According to Dr. Perry, “the human brain is not designed for the modern world.”
It is suited for the communal life of the smaller communities that Oprah has described.
However, as technology develops, people spend more and more time on their electronic devices and less in day-to-day relationships with each other.
Parents will obviously not give children their full attention if distracted by cellphones or computers.
This leads to the dysfunction of the children’s neural networks and to unhealthy rhythm and reward patterns.
Modern children tend to grow up lacking both stress coping abilities and feeling for other people.
Children and teenagers spend huge amounts of time online.
However, online relationships and interactions lack the depth of the close social relationships needed for healthy psychological development.
Studies show that college students are now 30 percent less empathetic than they were just 20 years ago.
The continuing growth of the urban environment is creating a world of isolated individuals amongst millions of strangers.
Isolation, loneliness, and depression are common in modern life, whereas in traditional cultures, people tended to be rooted in “therapeutic webs” of about 60 to 100 people.
The result is a kind of collective pain and trauma affecting the human species.

zh-TW.content: 第七部分，結論
本書帶領我們走上一趟旅程，改變我們對自身、他人和我們所生活世界的看法。
書中專注討論人生經驗中三個相關聯的的方面。
第一個是創傷，即是任何對我們人生造成負面影響的極度痛苦或困擾的經驗。
書中描述的第二個則是韌性，這種能力可以處理人生中的壓力和過往的創傷。
最後，書中還討論了從創傷中復原的治癒過程以及要到達韌性的奮鬥努力。
治癒的關鍵就在於理解「已發生的事」而不僅是「治療」症狀或影響。
儘管這些趨勢令人擔心，作者們仍保持審慎樂觀，因為人類有淵遠流長的適應事蹟。
歐普拉敘述了她是如何克服個人創傷以及在工作中幫助他人。
培理醫生相信，如同嬰兒一樣，人類這個物種有能力透過意識到問題和採取正向行動來改變。
我們需要去面對我們的「集體歷史創傷」。
既然個人的大腦可以重新設置，我們的集體意識也可以。
為了向前邁進，社會能正視歷史中創傷的部分，詢問「我們經歷了什麼？」然後處理問題。
神經序列治療模式可以且需要被應用，如此我們才能重新連結彼此的關係。
創傷後啟發的智慧是可能發生的。
歐普拉建議正在面對創傷的人們，「踏出他們的過往陰影，走進未來的光明之中」。

en-US.content: Part 7  Conclusion
This book takes us on a journey that can change our view of ourselves, others, and the world we live in.
It focuses on three connected areas of human experience.
The first, trauma, is any deeply distressing or disturbing experience that affects our lives negatively.
Second, the book describes resilience, the ability to cope with the stresses of life and past trauma.
Finally, the book discusses the process of healing from trauma and the struggle to achieve resilience.
The key to healing is understanding “what happened” not merely “treating” the symptoms or effects.
Despite these alarming trends, the authors remain cautiously optimistic because of humanity’s long history of adaptation.
Oprah describes how she overcame her personal traumas and how she has helped others in her work.
Dr. Perry believes that, like infants, the human species is capable of changing through awareness and positive action.
We need to face our “collective historical trauma.”
As individuals’ brains can be rewired, so can our collective consciousness.
Society can confront the traumatic areas of its history, ask “What happened?” and then address the issues in order to move on.
The Neurosequential Model can be, and needs to be applied, so that we can reconnect to each other.
A post-traumatic wisdom is possible.
Oprah advises people who are confronting their trauma to “step out of their history and into the path of their future.”

description.zh-TW:
一本治癒與協助克服創傷的書

在《你經歷了什麼？談創傷、韌性與治癒》一書中，布魯斯・培理醫生和歐普拉・溫芙蕾帶領我們踏上一段旅程，幫助我們了解自身以及他人的問題，還有我們身處世界的大小煩擾事。
知名談話節目主持人歐普拉與心理學家培理醫生討論了與人生經驗有根本關聯的三方面──創傷、韌性以及治癒。創傷是種深層的痛苦經驗，它會持續影響我們。先前的創傷會讓生活日益艱難，韌性則是處理其生活壓力的能力。而治癒為藉由先理解「發生的事」並一步步往韌性邁進，以此來克服創傷。
作者們一開始藉真實案例討論受創傷影響的人們以及創傷如何揮之不去地困擾他們當前的生活情況。他們拆解創傷如何對我們大腦造成實際的生理改變，而導致核心調節網絡機能失調。作者們再藉由討論嬰兒的生命經驗，描述人類富有規律的生活結構與其每日的自然壓力及壓力應對。
創傷可能會對整個群體造成影響，還可能會世世代代承繼下去。事實上，沒有人能免於遭受創傷。由於當今居住於大城市的人們正逐漸變得離群孤立，主要溝通皆透過科技設備，使得整個現代世界都正歷經創傷。我們之中許多人不再有機會接觸到傳統社會中的「精神支持人際網」。因此，治癒便需要以全球的規模來實行。我們都需要去檢視「已發生的事」，才能為我們自己與這個世界建立一個正向的未來。
